history.content:
113 is power electronics: buck converters, DC-DC converters etc.  It's a different part of circuit design in that in typical analog (105/140) design we think in terms of the frequency domain, whereas in power electronics the circuits rely on time domain analysis, where the current and voltage waveforms have to be engineered such that minimal power is wasted in the converter.  Its definitely much different.


117 is from what I've heard standard E/M theory with some transmission lines added in; I admittedly haven't taken the class so maybe someone else can comment on it. 


——

Regarding EE117: @8095 

tldr; It’s relatively lightweight. Exams are fair and not meant to trick you. Labs are short, he refers to them as “mini-labs” and it just consists of taking measurements — no reports. Generously curved (B+ average I think?).

children.subject: OP here. Thank you Rohit! Anyone have more information about 117, or the workloads of the classes?

history.content: Both of these classes fit in my schedule next semester and seem pretty interesting, but I don't know much about them other than the official descriptions. I know they have very different topics, but I'm not sure where each would take me. Does anyone have any perspective on these two (especially 113 because I couldn't find much)? I've already taken the prerequisites for both.
history.subject: EE113 or EE117
